events.name: Big data applied to Google Play apps
events.description:
David is an expert on big data, he's been involved with it for some years now, he built a model to improve +XX million in yearly revenue on growing Search product.

He will be telling us about how to use machine learning in the context of recommending Google Play apps, also will discuss the challenges of working on Search ranking for Play apps. 

    - David Lluncor.

7:00pm - Food And Drinks.
7:30pm - Speaker.
8:15pm - Questions.

events.name: GDG Berkeley goes to Maptoberfest
events.description:
Join us in San Francisco on October 29 and celebrate Google Maps innovation led by developers. See how other developers have transformed their apps and sites using maps. Learn how Google is enabling new possibilities for developers, from enhanced personalization to analyzing data at massive scale. Register for Maptoberfest and join our community of developers who are exploring location-enabled technology. Please note that all event attendees must register for this event at https://www.maptoberfest.com/register

# Meet the man behind the map

Brian McClendon leads the Google Maps team, which includes Google Maps for Mobile, Google Earth, Street View, Waze, and Google’s local business efforts. Google Maps services are used by more than 1 billion people every month. In September, Brian received the Champions of the Earth award from the United Nations Environmental Programme.

Brian joined Google in 2004 via the acquisition of Keyhole, the precursor to Google Earth, which he co-founded. He also built advanced computer graphics hardware and software at Silicon Graphics. He holds ten patents, including ones for KML, the open standard for displaying geospatial data on web-based maps.

events.name: GDG Berkeley goes to Google Cloud Platform Live
events.description:
Learn about the next generation of cloud computing at Google's cloud Platform Live.

https://www.gcp-live.com/register

The event will be broadcasted, but we also have a 20% discount for GDG berkeley members, so you would only pay 120$ if you do it this week. Contact us to get the discount.

Don't miss out in this opportunity to meet the makers of the next generation of cloud technologies.

In the live event there will be two tracks:

 Track 1 will take you through everything you need to do to build a scalable app, from making architectural decisions about whether to build on IaaS or PaaS through to deployment and monitoring. We’ll show you an end-to-end development cycle - deep on code, with real examples to make your apps better.

Track 2 will address hot topics in cloud computing, from privacy and security to bleeding-edge container technologies.

And during our keynote, you’ll get to hear our vision for the next generation of cloud computing.

More details to come.

events.name: Crash the DevFest in Mountain View
events.description:
The DevFest is a full day event in Google Mountain View with workshops and talks by Google developers that will introduce us to new technologies and ideas.

Come join us and enjoy a day of swag, learning and treats by Google. There's more information here:
http://devfest2014.gdgsv.com/

Please register here too:
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/gdg-silicon-valley-devfest-2014-tickets-13571156695

There will be a bus leaving from SF, and if there's enough of us we can get a bus to leave from Berkeley too.

YOU NEED A TICKET.

events.name: Why AngularJS?
events.description:
If you haven’t tried Angular yet, you’re missing out on why people say JavaScript is the most flexible language in the world.

HTML is great for declaring static documents, but it falters when we try to use it for declaring dynamic views in web-applications. AngularJS lets you extend HTML vocabulary for your application. The resulting environment is extraordinarily expressive, readable, and quick to develop.

AngularJS is a toolset for building the framework most suited to your application development. It is fully extensible and works well with other libraries. Every feature can be modified or replaced to suit your unique development workflow and feature needs. Read on to find out how.

Come find out why you should be using Angular, learn about the basic concepts of Angular and how to structure a big Angular codebase. 

- David Silva is one of the founders of GDG Berkeley, he's been using Angular for a couple of years and is currently a senior front-end developer at Doctor On Demand, a healthcare company.

events.name: AngularJS Casual Workshop
events.description:
Since some of you asked about how to 'properly' use Angular, we can meet this Saturday to share some actual implementation tips and ideas so you can learn to write AngularJS applications the way the professionals do.

David will be walking us through a sample application, he's been coding in Angular for two years, currently 0working for a healthcare company, using Angular in an application that's 12000 lines of JavaScript long.

events.name: Building Realtime Applications with Firebase
events.description:
Modern applications are supposed to be responsive: Facebook updates your news feed instantly, Twitter posts new tweets after they are created, and Google Docs immediately show changes to your spreadsheet or word document. Current web protocols (like HTTP) and paradigms (like RESTful API's) aren't designed for a responsive internet. Until now, one would have to implement their own solutions, often spending months (if not years) of development time to create a storage and sync platform. 

Enter Firebase, a realtime backend for your applications which stores and syncs your JSON data like Dropbox stores and syncs your files and folders. We will explore the challenges of building a system like this, talk about potential solutions, and demonstrate the capabilities of Firebase by building a cross-platform realtime application.

BENEFITS OF ATTENDING:
 Attending this workshop will give you:
1) a better understanding of the difficulties faced in building and scaling a modern cross-platform application
2) an overview of the current tools in the market and which problems they solve
3) a solid understanding of how Firebase can be used to create highly scalable web and mobile applications
4) some sweet Firebase swag that is guaranteed to make all your friends jealous!

BIO:

Jenny is a Developer Advocate on Firebase at Google. In this role she helps developers build realtime stuff on all sorts of platforms. Previously she worked in a wide variety of software roles from robotics at NASA, to developer advocacy for Google Glass. 

She is passionate about education, especially on the subjects of technology and science. If she's away from her laptop, she's probably skating around a roller derby track, or hanging from aerial silk.
events.how_to_find_us: The main door closes at 6, so we will have a sign on it with a number to text or call so we can get you.

events.name: Kimono: Scraping the web with a chrome extension
events.description:
A short introduction to kimono - a chrome extension that lets you easily scrape the web, turning any website into an API. One of kimono's features is an integration with google sheets, enabling users to pipe live data from kimono APIs directly into a spreadsheet. Building with google sheets has powerful benefits but presents interesting technical challenges.

Speaker bio: "Andy leads R&D at kimono labs. He has been getting at the art of the possible for nearly 15 years, most recently as a Principal Technologist at frog design in New York and San Francisco. His public installations can be viewed in New York and Singapore, while privately he drove innovation through collaboration with business and R&D at Disney, P&G, GE, MTV, SAP, the NYPL and many others. Prior to frog he helped invent new approaches to data visualization with the seminal design firm Thinkmap. Andy studied comparative religions at Wesleyan University in Connecticut, and now lives in Berkeley, where he contemplates alternatives to the clock while trampolining with the kids."

events.name: Casual Polymer workshop
events.description:
Hi developers! the community is starting to grow and we've shared some great moments,  this year we will try to have more workshops and interesting events, not just talks. Polymer sounds like a great one to being with.

The folks at Google that work in Polymer have put together a very complete guide to use it, in a casual workshop every attendee can work on its own or in small groups following the tutorials at the desired pace and a couple experienced developers can answer any question that's not addressed. I have a bunch of Google stickers to share too.

What's Polymer?

Welcome to the future

Web Components usher in a new era of web development based on encapsulated and interoperable custom elements that extend HTML itself. Polymer makes it possible to take advantage of this new standards in current browsers, and adds extra functions to extend their power.

Learn more about polymer in their site.

If there are ideas or things you want to know about let us know, if you want to give a talk or a workshop we can put it together too. I'm getting together some content for Android and wear for next months!

what do you need?

The guides and work are for developers of any level, we will use very little JS, is mostly HTML and CSS. 

For code I recommend you use Brackets, is the best editor of HTML and CSS.

This event will be super casual, and we have no sponsors yet, if you can bring some snacks or drinks to share with others it will be appreciated. We will have coffee, tea and water here.

events.name: Kubernetes workshop with Brian Dorsey from Google
events.description:
Join us for a hands-on walkthrough of deploying and managing applications using Google's open source Kubernetes (http://kubernetes.io). 

We'll deploy a simple application built with several different containers, and walk through how Kubernetes services allow containers to find and talk to each other over the network. Then we'll scale it up, give new versions a small percentage of traffic, and then do rolling upgrades of all containers to new versions.

Please bring a laptop with you to the workshop. If possible, please create a Google Cloud Platform (https://cloud.google.com/) project and install the gcloud SDK (https://cloud.google.com/sdk/) before the workshop.

Brian Dorsey -  I'm a Developer Advocate on the Google Cloud Developer Relations team. This means I help you build with our APIs. I focus on the open source Kubernetes cluster manager and our Cloud Platform, especially Compute Engine and Cloud Storage. I write sample code and create demos, present at conferences, and create screencasts. Feel free to drop me a note if you have any questions about our APIs.I've taught Python at the University of Washington & spoken at both PyCon US & PyCon Japan. I'm a bit of a Python fan. (understatement) I'm currently learning Go and enjoying it.
events.how_to_find_us: The door is usually closed on weekends, text the number I'll leave at the entrance to gain access.

events.name: Dart Code Lab, with Google's Dart team in SF
events.description:
Dart Code Lab, with Google's Dart team
April 27, San Francisco

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/dart-code-lab-tickets-16104627374

Come to the Dart Code Lab to have fun, play with Dart, and meet engineers from Google's Dart team and other Dart programmers! You must know how to program, but no previous knowledge of Dart is required.

During this Code Lab you will have the opportunity to explore Dart on the client side or the server side—or both. You will go through the process of building one or two simple applications in Dart, using Dart tools such as Dart Editor. The finished web application will run in all modern browsers and, together with the server-side part, will be ready to deploy.

The event is free, but you have to sign up using the eventbrite link, RSVPs in meetup won't guarantee your entrance.

events.name: Startup Weekend Immigration
events.description:
Hi developers!

With some friends I'm organizing an event for the end of May, a Startup Weekend is like a hackathon but less technically oriented, the idea is to build the beginning of startup during the weekend. There will be mentors and workshops from companies like firebase, google cloud, proto.io, unshackled, and many opportunities to meet great people and learn new technical and business skills.

This is a short video introducing the format:

https://vimeo.com/eighteeneighty/swtrailer

This particular event will be focusing in startup ideas around immigration, come with your ideas that can make life easier for current or aspiring immigrants or join a team and work together for an interesting cause.

There are more details of the event here:

http://www.up.co/communities/usa/san-francisco/startup-weekend/5961

And you can get tickets here:

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/startup-weekend-immigration-tickets-16092734803?discount=hacker25

Using coupon `hacker25` will get you discounted tickets.

Hope to see you and your friends there!

events.name: Study Group
events.description:
Want to get better at a particular programming language or technique? Learning some new thing?

Creating something cool and want some feedback?

Or just need a calm place to sit Sat afternoon with good Internet?

Let's get together and help each other for a few hours! bring some snacks and drinks to share, and make new programming friends.

If you need some guides or inspiration, Google recently published this codelabs with amazing content in different topics:

https://io2015codelabs.appspot.com/

We're planning on hosting this at least once a month to provide a great space for the community to interact besides talks and workshops. Your feedback as always is greatly appreciated! If you're interested in a particular topic or event, or would like to help make the community stronger and better events let us know!

events.name: Google Next San Francisco (free google cloud event)
events.description:
Let's join our friends in SF. At Google Next, you'll hear how developers and IT professionals are using Google Cloud Platform to make all kinds of amazing new things. Hear from our experts, get hands-on technical training and find out how customers and peers are using next-generation Google technologies in mobile, big data, compute, networking and security to build and scale faster than ever before.

Make sure to register here too:
https://cloudplatformonline.com/NEXT_Google_Cloud_Platform_Experience_SanFrancisco.html

events.name: Study Group
events.description:
Want to get better at a particular programming language or technique? Learning some new thing?

Creating something cool and want some feedback?

Or just need a calm place to sit Sat afternoon with good Internet?

Let's get together and help each other for a few hours! have some snacks and coffee, and make new programming friends.

If you need some guides or inspiration, Google recently published this codelabs with amazing content in different topics:

https://io2015codelabs.appspot.com/

We're planning on hosting this every now and then to provide a great space for the community to interact besides talks and workshops. Your feedback as always is greatly appreciated! If you're interested in a particular topic or event, or would like to help make the community stronger and better events let us know!
events.how_to_find_us: ring the bell or text me at 415 712 64 29 for access*

events.name: DevFest Berkeley
events.description:
GDG DevFests are large, community-run events that can offer speaker sessions across multiple product areas, all-day hack-a-thons, code labs, and more. In 2015, the official DevFest Season runs from September 01st through November 30th.

We have a very exciting event coming up, with our friends from Google Cloud, they will be bringing a Cloud Spin rig to take some cool pictures and explain how do they work. 

Followed by some lunch, and then by a workshop to get you started using Big Query.

We will have lots of google promotional materials, and some good surprises!

Schedule.

11 - 12 Google Cloud Spin

12 - 1  Lunch, take pictures and make new friends

1  - 4  Google Big Query workshop

4 - 5  Women TechMakers launch and Community presentations

Cloud Spin: Mark & Sandeep will walk through features of the Google Cloud Platform used in building the Google Cloud Spin demo shown at recent #GCPNext events. The demo uses an orchestrated set of smartphones to capture multi-angle views of the same event, upload them to the cloud and have them stitched together in real time to create a  single 180-degree snapshot of that moment. 

Demo: They will have a live demo setup that folks can stop by and participate in!

BigQuery Workshop: Data is great, but insights are better. Learn how you can use BigQuery to analyze terabytes of data in seconds using SQL, without ever setting up a cluster or learning a complicated new syntax. Sandeep and Mark will give an overview of BigQuery and the motivations behind data processing at Google, and then you can get your hands dirty writing your own queries!


Speaker Profiles

Sandeep started coding and creating websites when he was 12 and hasn't stopped. He is passionate about building easy-to-use products people love. Before Google, he founded an IoT startup in agriculture and developed educational HTML5 games. At Google, Sandeep's goal is to make cloud easy and help developers create the next big thing. Sandeep loves video games, making music, and martial arts, and has Bachelors in Marketing and Computer Science.

Mark Mandel is a Developer Advocate for the Google Cloud Platform. Hailing from Australia, Mark built his career developing backend web applications which included several widely adopted open source projects, and running an international conference in Melbourne for several years. Since then he has focused on becoming a polyglot developer, building systems in Go, JRuby and Clojure on a variety of infrastructures. In his spare time he plays with his dog, trains martial arts and reads too much fantasy literature.

For more information.

DevFest: https://developers.google.com/events/devfest/

CloudSpin: https://twitter.com/googlecloudspin

Google Big Query: https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/what-is-bigquery

We are dedicated to creating welcoming and friendly learning environments. http://bridgefoundry.org/code-of-conduct/

events.name: CodeGirl screening
events.description:
http://www.codegirlmovie.com/

Join high school-aged girls from around the world as they try to better their community through technology and collaboration in this thrilling, heartfelt documentary.

By 2017, the app market will be valued at $77 Billion. Over 80% of these developers are male. The Technovation Challenge aims to change that by empowering girls worldwide to develop apps for an international competition. From rural Moldova to urban Brazil to suburban Massachusetts, CODEGIRL follows teams who dream of holding their own in the world’s fastest-growing industry. The winning team gets $10K to complete and release their app, but every girl discovers something valuable along the way.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cRb5iel-3Ck

http://www.codegirlmovie.com/

Doors open at 6:30pm, and screening starts at 7:15pm.

events.name: Off Planet VR | virtual reality and 360 video experiences
events.description:
A very good friend is throwing an event that I think you'd like to attend.

With Virtual and Augmented Reality projected revenues to hit 

$150 billion by 2020

, emerging Bay Area companies are at the forefront of building the Metaverse: a new form of presence.  

On Thursday Dec 3rd, from 6-9pm you're invited to connect with scores of Bay Area VR pioneers, developers and UC Berkeley students for a night of virtual fun and games in the heart of Downtown Berkeley at NextSpace. Discover your next adventure. #OffPlanet.

Off Planet VR is a 3-hour exploration of virtual reality and 360 video experiences from the architects, developers and dreamers of this radical new territory, produced by Berkeley filmmaker Siciliana Trevino and sponsored by the Berkeley Startup Cluster. 

Siciliana will be presenting her first VR/360 project for Oculus Rift, "Berkeley in 360", a virtual tour of Berkeley.

Special guests include SpaceVR CEO, Ryan Holmes, who will discuss  plans to bring a VR camera to the International Space Station to allow anyone to experience space on any mobile, desktop or VR device. 

Explore demos from:

High Fidelity

 - Open source software for shared VR

SpaceVR

 - Virtual Reality Space Exploration

LucidCam

 - World's first consumer camera for VR 

Borrowed Light Studios

 - Step into a Vincent Van Gogh painting 

and more!

RSVP at http://offplanetvr.splashthat.com

events.name: Greet 2016
events.description:
Hi GDG Berkeley, happy 2016! 

We're very excited for a new year and all the cool things we can do, let's have a couple of beers and pizza this Friday, talk about the new year, share your ideas and meet new friends.
events.how_to_find_us: Sent an email with my number, if you didn't get it, post in the event wall when you arrive and I'll come and get you.

events.name: Berkeley Startup job Fair
events.description:
https://www.localwisejobs.com/blog/berkeley-startup-job-fair/

Looking for a job at a startup? Join us on January 28 at NextSpace for the first ever Berkeley Startup Job Fair! The event is co-hosted by Localwise and the City of Berkeley’s Office of Economic Development.

All community members are welcome! This is an inclusive event, focused on promoting diversity in tech.

You’ll be surrounded by some of the world’s most innovative startups. Better yet, they want to hire you. Bring your resume as you may just land a job with a hot startup. Both technical and non-technical jobs are available.

Participating Startups:

Massdrop

Magoosh

LeadGenius

PandaDoc

Josephine

Thistle

Fluid

Mind My Education

CryptoMove

Telnexus

Dray Technologies

Grafty

Diassess

Kuli Kuli

Building Robotics

Expedite Financial

ProfHire

Trilogy Interactive

Berkeleyside

LeapYear

1-Page

Black Girls Code

Vyrill

Remeeting

Captricity

+ more!

There will also be:

Locally-made snacks & drinks from Kuli Kuli, Black Medicine, Uptown Juice Company, and CupCakin Bakeshop

Free resume review by local career coaches Julia Silbergeld Tom BallantyneKellin Defiel, and Hilary Romanoff

Free professional headshots

Appearance by Mayor Tom Bates

+ other great surprises!

Spaaaaaace is limited. Sign up for free today!

Get your tickets here https://www.eventbrite.com/e/berkeley-startup-job-fair-tickets-19924378352

events.name: Android development for beginners live hangout
events.description:
There are 1.4 billion android users in the world, want to learn how to tap this market? Then join us for a 90 minute live-streamed Android developer event on Feb 4 at 3 PM PDT from wherever you are! Katherine Kuan, Lyla Fujiwara and Frank van Puffelen will show you how to start developing on android, give you insider tips and answer questions, Live! They will also show you how take android courses completely free of charge and how to get 1 on 1 help from android facilitators. #StudyJamsLive #devstudyjam #GDG #Google

Join the event and get more information https://plus.google.com/events/c91ccjj6745t0r4e4sh9ki3sqd0

events.name: (san francisco) Building Realtime, Scalable Android  iOT Apps + Win a Nexus 5X!
events.description:
Our friends in App a Month SF invited us to an event that I feel you might like:

You MUST RSVP to EVENTBRITE at http://appamonthfeb2016.eventbrite.com Demo Signup: Leave a short description of your product at https://www.facebook.com/appamonth

Hello Makers, This App A Month come take an Android crashcourse with David East and see how Firebase and Firebase UI improve your getting started experience with Android.

Then Sandeep Dinesh will show you how to to build a scalable, cross platform real time IoT "Simon Says" game that can be accessed around the world by millions of people using containers and Kubernetes.

Sign up to demo your App to receive feedback and increase traction and community engagement. Enter the raffle at the door to win a Nexus 5X!

6:30-7:15: Registration, meet and greet, food and drinks

7:15-7:40: Android Crashcourse with David East

7:45-8:10: Realtime IoT Apps with Sandeep Dinesh

8:10-8:30: Demos from Members of App A Month

8:30-9:00: Networking food and drinks

Thank you

App a Month Team

events.name: Hack Summit
events.description:
HackSummit is the largest programming conference in history, featuring programming language creators, open-source  contributors, and thought leaders

From the comfort of your home, the conference is completely virtual, presented by Pluralsight Virtual Conference Technology provided by  Crowdcast

Upon registering, you will have access to all recorded speaker talks

Our Goals are to educate wizards of all languages and skill-sets, raise money for coding nonprofits, to encourage mentorship among software developers

You'll have the chance to interact and ask questions to speakers

The organizers are making a special invitation to us, use code BDGB for free access.

events.name: Android Study Jam, free workshop for Android beginners
events.description:
Google Developers Study Jams
Android for Beginners Udacity Course

What are Study Jams
Study Jams are community-organized study groups around Google online developer courses. The goal is to support as many students as possible in completing the course, thereby raising the technical level of the community. We will be working together in the Android class for beginners from Udacity with the help of some experienced developers.
https://www.udacity.com/account/affiliate/GoogleStudyJams

The Study Jams for Android for Beginners is best suited for two audiences those new to programming or those with programming experience who have never used Android.

What students get
Personal tutoring on the course material
Community setting to support course learning
Swag pack
Google-offered Study Jams completion certificate
Discount on the Android Nanodegree upon course completion
Opportunity to join Google Launchpad with completed app, pending app quality

Support from Google

Swag - Swag for students
Study Jams certificate - Google-provided Study Jams certificate to students who complete the course, submit a final project, and attend the Study Jams sessions

G+ community for Students - Students may join a public G+ community to meet other Study Jam participants and discuss questions, share apps, etc.
https://plus.google.com/u/0/communities/107779414017676143474

Important, we will be meeting one night a week for five weeks, the first week is Wednesday Feb 24th and the followings will be march 1, march 8, march 15, march 22. Onsite we will go through the class material with the facilitators and answer questions, and you're expected to do some extra exercises at home. Creativity and exploration is encouraged.

Find more information at http://developerstudyjams.com/

events.name: Scalable Microservices, IoT, Mobile and More with gRPC, Docker, and Kubernetes
events.description:
Abstract:

 Building scalable real-time applications that can communicate with IoT devices, wearables, phones, and other platforms is a tricky proposition at the best of times. You have to deal with all the hard problems: device network performance, real-time bidirectional communication, scalable infrastructures and distributed system complexity. By leveraging some popular open source libraries such as Docker, Kubernetes and gRPC, we are able to mitigate many of these issues to quickly build a scalable, real-time experience that can be accessed around the world by millions of people. During this talk, we will look at how gRPC can be used as a performant real-time communication framework that works across platforms such as wearables and embedded devices as well as languages, such as Go, Node.js and Java. We will also combine this with Kubernetes’ powerful ability to orchestrate containers at scale, handling and coordinating large amounts of traffic from all these devices.

Bio: 

Sandeep started coding and creating websites when he was 12 and hasn't stopped. He is passionate about building easy-to-use products people love. Before Google, he founded an IoT startup in agriculture and developed educational HTML5 games. At Google, Sandeep's goal is to make cloud easy and help developers create the next big thing. Sandeep loves video games, making music, and martial arts, and has Bachelors in Marketing and Computer Science.


Also, we created a slack group for our members, head over it to ask questions about the events, job offers, or make new friends! request an invite here:  http://gdgberkeley.herokuapp.com/

events.name: Android Study Jam, free workshop for Android beginners
events.description:
Google Developers Study Jams
Android for Beginners Udacity Course

What are Study Jams
Study Jams are community-organized study groups around Google online developer courses. The goal is to support as many students as possible in completing the course, thereby raising the technical level of the community. We will be working together in the Android class for beginners from Udacity with the help of some experienced developers.
https://www.udacity.com/account/affiliate/GoogleStudyJams

The Study Jams for Android for Beginners is best suited for two audiences those new to programming or those with programming experience who have never used Android.

What students get
Personal tutoring on the course material
Community setting to support course learning
Swag pack
Google-offered Study Jams completion certificate
Discount on the Android Nanodegree upon course completion
Opportunity to join Google Launchpad with completed app, pending app quality

Support from Google

Swag - Swag for students
Study Jams certificate - Google-provided Study Jams certificate to students who complete the course, submit a final project, and attend the Study Jams sessions

G+ community for Students - Students may join a public G+ community to meet other Study Jam participants and discuss questions, share apps, etc.
https://plus.google.com/u/0/communities/107779414017676143474

Important, we will be meeting one night a week for five weeks, the first week is Wednesday Feb 24th and the followings will be march 1, march 8, march 15, march 22. Onsite we will go through the class material with the facilitators and answer questions, and you're expected to do some extra exercises at home. Creativity and exploration is encouraged.

Find more information at http://developerstudyjams.com/

events.name: JavaScript Design Patterns CodeJam
events.description:
Let's get together and sharpen our javascript skills with this great Udacity class. Everyone can work at their own pace, and we will be around to help whoever needs a hand.

Course description

This course covers methods for organizing your code, both conceptually and literally. You’ll learn the importance of separating concerns when writing JavaScript, gaining hands-on experience along the way. Separating concerns can be done with or without an organizational library or framework. We’ll learn how to separate concerns without one, and then we’ll explore an organizational library together. You’ll also learn strategies for exploring other libraries and frameworks on your own.

By the end of this course, you’ll understand (from experience) the importance of code organization, and how to implement it with either vanilla JavaScript or an organizational library or framework. Your applications will start looking clean and professional—not just to your users, but also to anyone who looks at the code driving your applications.

https://www.udacity.com/course/javascript-design-patterns--ud989

NextSpace is doing an open house week starting May 9, where anybody that's serious about coworking can work here for free!

Bring $5 if you’d like to chip in for pizza! 

We’re going to do a head count and order pizza at 6:35pm. If you’re going to be late, please let us know in advance

events.name: d3 w/Angular 2 & TypeScript, Angular Universal, Transforms. Google Mountain View
events.description:
Our friends from the Angular meetup in Mountain View are inviting us to join them for the next event. We will provide transportation from Berkeley to Google Mountain View and Back. If you haven't been at Google and want a chance to see campus and meet some cool googlers this is the perfect opportunity!

This event is also done in partnership with the Modern Web meetup group.

Presentation Abstracts (full agenda in next section):

Creating d3 Components with Angular 2  and TypeScript 
Speaker: Aysegul Yonet

By creating d3 components in Angular2 you gain even more declarative API. Angular allows you to construct your own declarative components, so you can easily reason about visualizations you create.

Angular Universal: bridging the gap between static and dynamic web apps Speaker: Patrick Stapleton (aka PatrickJS)

Before we have single-page apps we were rendering our application on the server which is different from how we develop apps today.  In this talk, we will go over how we can use Angular Universal to develop static web apps.  We will also go over how we can use Angular Universal for dynamic websites to increase perceived performance of our single-page apps today.  Then we will combine these two worlds in one application that can do both.  By the end of the talk, you will understand the difference between these two types of web applications and how we can use Angular Universal to build one super app. 

transformRequest and transformResponse: efficiency in disguise [Lightning Talk] 
Speaker: Dvid Silva

Transforms are a great place to place code; move the logic out from your controllers and services, make your code easier to read and reuse. 

--------------- 


Can't attend in person?  

• Recording will be posted after the event

Agenda: 

4PM - Buses Leave from Berkeley
6PM - Doors open, Food, Drinks and Socializing 
6:30 - Welcome & Angular Update 
6:35 - Creating d3 Components with Angular 2  and TypeScript - Aysegul Yonet 
7:05 - Angular Game 
7:15 - Angular Universal: bridging the gap between static and dynamic web apps - Patrick Stapleton 
7:45 - Angular Jeopardy 
7:55 - Lightning Talk: transformRequest and transformResponse: efficiency in disguise - Dvid Silva 
8:13 - MVgo's last West Bayshore shuttle leaves stop #11 (Charleston Rd @ Huff Ave SW), please plan accordingly 
8:22 - Angular Game 
8:30 - Speaker/Angular Core Team panel 
8:50 - Thank you & Raffle 
8:55 - Office hours and socializing 

9:00 - Buses leave back to Berkeley


***Guest Badging System*** 

We recommended pre-printed badges.  To get a pre-printed badge, you must have a Yes RSVP (with a full first and last name listed) by 12p on Fri 7/15. Please note that badges cannot be created with incomplete name information.

If a pre-printed badge is not available for you when you arrive, you may create one on-demand, but due to the logistics of this process, please note there may be a long wait and this option will only be available until 6:30pm.  

Their event details can be found here, http://www.meetup.com/AngularJS-MTV/events/232040136  but it is not necesary to RSVP there to attend. 

If you work in the south bay and need a ride back to Berkeley with us, that can be arranged, send me a private message letting me know.
events.how_to_find_us: We're meeting in the little lobby outside Next Space, to get to the buses. Departure is at 4 sharp.

events.name: partner event: Progressive web apps
events.description:
Progressive Web Apps are experiences that combine the best of the web and the best of apps. 

They load quickly, even on flaky networks, can re-engage with users by sending web push notifications, have an icon on the home screen and load as top-level, full screen experiences.

In this event, we'll explain the what, why and how of Progressive Web Apps, and work through some code labs to give you some hands-on experience (bring your laptop!) Please join us to learn about the future of the web with Progressive Web Apps, why they are important and how to build and deploy them effectively.

If you'd like to attend, register here:  https://events.withgoogle.com/pwa-roadshow-north-america/registrations/new/

We're not planning on providing transportation, but if enough of us want to go together we could figure it out.

events.name: Global Game Jam
events.description:
http://globalgamejam.org/2017/jam-sites/google-cloud-playcrafting-ggj-launchpad-sf

The Global Game Jam® (GGJ) is the world's largest game jam event (game creation) taking place around the world at physical locations. Think of it as a hackathon focused on game development. It is the growth of an idea that in today’s heavily connected world, we could come together, be creative, share experiences and express ourselves in a multitude of ways using video games – it is very universal. The weekend stirs a global creative buzz in games, while at the same time exploring the process of development, be it programming, iterative design, narrative exploration or artistic expression. It is all condensed into a 48 hour development cycle. The GGJ encourages people with all kinds of backgrounds to participate and contribute to this global spread of game development and creativity.

The structure of a jam is usually that everyone gathers on Friday late afternoon, watches a short video keynote with advice from leading game developers, and then a secret theme is announced. All sites worldwide are then challenged to make games based on that same theme, with games to be completed by Sunday afternoon. In January 2016, we had over 600 locations in 93 countries create 6866 games in one weekend! GGJ 2017 is January 20-22 at a location near you… if not you can make one of your own. The jam is known for helping foster new friendships, increase confidence and opportunities within the community. The jam is always an intellectual challenge. People are invited to explore new technology tools, trying on new roles in development and testing their skills to do something that requires them to design, develop create, test and make a new game in the time span of 48 hours.

The GGJ stimulates collaboration and is not a competition.

Register on the site's event.

events.description:

events.name: International Women's Day 2017 - Mountain View
events.description:
The Women Techmakers Global Event Series Celebrating International Women's Day.

Why are we doing this?

Google strives to cultivate a wholly inclusive workplace around the globe. A key component of that vision is empowering women to pursue their dreams and build tools that change the world.

Having a diversity of perspectives and ideas leads to better decision-making, more relevant products, and makes the industry much more interesting. We believe that by creating the right environments, programs and policies, women in tech are better positioned to drive transformational change in the industry and beyond.

Women Techmakers is Google's global program and brand for women in technology. Kicked off in 2012 by then VP of Google[x] Megan Smith, Women Techmakers is now led by Women in Technology Advocate Natalie Villalobos and a global team of Googlers who are passionate about empowering women in technology through increased visibility, community, and resources

Find more information here: https://www.womentechmakers.com/iwd17

To attend, apply here: https://services.google.com/fb/forms/iwd17mtvsummit/

events.name: Space Exploration Using Angular
events.description:
As electronics become cheaper, smaller, and more widespread, the cost to build and launch new satellites is falling rapidly. However satellite mission operations is still performed using expensive, specialized software developed by individual operators in-house.

Quindar is a free, open-source project that empowers the developer community to build a mission operations platform for the space industry. We aim to create a modern, browser-based, real-time data visualization tool to monitor and operate spacecraft in flight. Angular allows the code to be modular, scalable, reusable, and collaborative.

AngularJS is going to space.

Google Developers Group Berkeley will host a workshop on how open-source software is being used in the space industry. Participants will enjoy a presentation and a hands-on workshop with Quindar.

Speaker: Sydney Lai

Sydney Lai is the head of business development at Audacy, a space startup providing continuous satellite connectivity. She will describe how space startups currently build for space and how open-source software is accelerating industry development.

Mentor: Chavi Malhotra

Chavi Malhotra is leading Quindar’s software development and community resources. She holds a Master of Science degree in software engineering from San Jose State University, and worked at Equifax and Macate Group before joining Audacy. She has a passion for web UI design, virtualization technologies, and computer networks.

Mentor: Taruni Gattu

Taruni Gattu leads Quindar’s front-end development. She holds a Master of Science degree in computer science from the University of Texas, and worked at ERP Analysts before joining Audacy.

AGENDA

6:00 PM Check-in + networking

6:30 PM Introductions to space startups, open-source, building Quindar with Angular, Audacy

7:00 PM Workshop

8:30PM Show and tell, share, feedback

9:00 PM Closing

PREREQUISITES

1) Install Git

2) Install Docker

https://docs.docker.com/engine/installation/

NOTES

*Bring your laptop to download from Github

* There is bicycle parking inside the building so bring your own lock and leave your bicycle at your own risk.  

* There is also street and garage parking. Check all signs for restrictions and fees.  

* Smile! We are recording and photographing this event.
events.how_to_find_us: Text me at 4157126429 and I'll get the door.

events.name: Developing Apps for Emerging Countries
events.description:
The next billion people going online live in emerging countries. This is a mobile-first reality, where a feature-phone or a smartphone is the main point of communication, local use of mobile apps and web is different and the infrastructure places strict limits on internet data volume.This subject is getting increased attention, and many projects are focusing on it, offering solutions ranging from guidelines to cater to a range of data plans and devices, to improving the infrastructure and bringing more affordable internet.

Getting a better picture of this will help you make your work more inclusive towards people in emerging countries, whether it is part of your job or your side project - there is still a lot to learn and even more to make.

In this talk Natalie will share her experience in the field, having researched it in Berlin, and now working on the ground in Nairobi, putting her learnings to practice. Some of the subjects we will cover include the local tech ecosystem, web apps vs. mobile apps vs. mobile sites vs. chatbots, common apps and devices, technical and product localization guidelines, technical limitations, how is this related to financial inclusion and why should the Silicon Savannah be on your mind.

--

Natalie is the co-founder of Connta, a platform for running an online store from a mobile phone that is focused on emerging countries, based in Nairobi. Prior to that she worked in the mobile industry in Berlin for 3.5 years, where her last position was a Backend Engineer at adjust - a mobile attribution and analytics company. She graduated with a B.Sc. in Computer and Software Engineering from the Technion, Israel, while working as a Silicon Integration Engineer at Intel. In her free time she is co-leading the Berlin chapters of Google Developer Groups Golang and Women Techmakers, volunteering with the Tunapanda coding school in Nairobi and sailing.

--

https://twitter.com/connta_app

https://twitter.com/NataliePis

https://www.linkedin.com/in/nataliepistunovich

events.name: BayFest DevFest
events.description:
Come join us as GDG San Francisco, GDG Berkeley, GDG Fremont, and GDG Oakdale come together to host a series of events over the course of three weekends.

Below is information copied over from GDG San Francisco's event page:

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Code Labs | San Francisco | October 28,[masked]am - 4pm

Kick off your DevFest with a guided tutorial exploring new Google technologies with hands on code labs.

Technical Talks | San Francisco | October 28,[masked]am - 4:30pm

This all day event will feature back to back speaker sessions on a variety of topics (Machine Learning, Android, IOT, Cloud & more!)

This event will be the perfect opportunity to put to work all of the new knowledge you've gained and work with others to a hack a project!

Tickets: bit.ly/DevFest17

Volunteer Opportunities: https://goo.gl/forms/0V6kLRmX2iIWUEtu1

Please message us if you have any question!

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

About DevFest:

GDG DevFests are large, community-run events that can offer speaker sessions across multiple product areas, all-day hack-a-thons, code labs, and more. Each GDG DevFest will be inspired by and uniquely tailored to the needs of the developer community that hosts it. While no two events will be exactly alike, each GDG DevFest will be powered by a shared belief that when developers come together to exchange ideas amazing things can happen.

events.name: SVG Compression
events.description:

events.name: Lessons learned growing an all remote/volunteer open-sourced coding community
events.description:
• What we'll do
We're happy to have Linda Peng as our speaker this month!
Linda is a developer at ActionKit.com and co-organizer at Women Who Code East Bay meetup.
She's interested in social justice, fandom, communities, making videos, recording music, and creating spaces for people to connect.
Follow her on Twitter (@lpnotes).

She is the creator of CodeBuddies (https://github.com/codebuddies), a project built up by multiple core contributors, and she will discuss valuable trials and lessons she's experienced in leading a popular open-sourced community.

We will have dinner provided at the event at no charge, so please feel free to come by after your busy workday. Attendees will enter in a raffle to win prizes anywhere from Firebase shirts to a Daydream VR set. One attendee will be chosen per meetup event.

Looking forward to seeing you all soon!

• What to bring

• Important to know

events.name: Accessing Accessible Accessibility
events.description:
Get excited! :) Our friend, Jennifer Wong will be joining us as our speaker!

Jennifer is a self-taught software engineer. She spends her days making the web a prettier and more user-friendly place. She has written for Net Magazine and had projects covered by Mashable, Engadget, Gizmodo, and more. Jenn is an avid conference speaker and loves eating, coding, and sleeping.

-------------------------------------------------
Accessing Accessible Accessibility

The World Health Organization states that one billion people live with disabilities. And estimates put internet usage with a screen reader as high as 3.4% of all internet traffic around the world. Web accessibility can help.

So what is web accessibility and who needs it? Is engineering accessibility enough? How do you build an cross-functional accessibility culture? And what can you do to prevent regressions?

I had all the same questions… and only four months to guarantee all our consumer user flows were accessible. Well, what happened? Come learn what it takes to lead a web accessibility movement within your company!

events.name: GDG Berkeley I/O Extended 2018
events.description:
Hello!

P.S In case you missed any of the sessions from Google I/O. https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLOU2XLYxmsIInFRc3M44HUTQc3b_YJ4-Y

events.name: Introduction to Deep Learning, TensorFlow, and Keras
events.description:
Hello everyone -
With all the excitement around what's new in TensorFlow and Keras, it's easy to get lost if this is your first go at machine learning. To help us get some of the deep learning basics down (and much more), we're very happy to invite Oswald Campesato as our speaker for the month of July!

About the talk :

A fast-paced introduction to Deep Learning concepts, such as activation functions, cost functions, back propagation, and then a quick dive into CNNs. Basic knowledge of vectors, matrices, and derivatives is helpful in order to derive the maximum benefit from this session.

Next we'll see a simple neural network using Keras, followed by an introduction to TensorFlow and TensorBoard. (Bonus points if you know Zorn's Lemma, the Well-Ordering Theorem, and the Axiom of Choice.)

Skill level: Beginner-friendly

About the speaker:

Oswald is a former PhD Candidate (ABD) in Mathematics, an education junkie (6 degrees), and an author of 19 technical books. He has worked for Oracle, AAA, and Just Systems of Japan, along with various startups. He has lived/worked in 5 countries on three continents, and in a previous career he worked in South America, Italy, and the French Riviera, and has traveled to over 70 countries on six continents. He has worked from C/C++/Java developer to CTO, comfortable in 4 languages, and dreams of becoming fluent in Japanese. Currently he is working in an AI start-up, and is an instructor at UCSC for a Deep Learning (100% TensorFlow) course, and conducts training in Deep Learning and Android.

Twitter: @ocampesato
events.how_to_find_us: Look for a 'GDG Berkeley' sign up on the door. Call the number written on the sign and that will alert us to let you in.

events.name: Build a Slack Greeter Bot w/ Code.xyz & Node.js - Non-Developer? Come & learn!
events.description:
We're happy to invite Janeth Ledezma to be our speaker for our August meetup!

About the talk:

"Slack is a popular communication/ collaboration platform for the workplace.

In this hands-on workshop, we will create a Slack bot that privately welcomes and guides new users when they join a channel using Slack's ephemeral message method. I will provide a code template to get us started in no time and will explain how to modify the code using Javascript. We will work with simple blocks of JavaScript code which can be combined, modified, and removed as you like to create your desired interactive experience. We will be building our bot right from the browser using Code.xyz - an online API editor built by the team at Standard Library.

What Is an Ephemeral Slack Message?

This Slack bot will post an ephemeral message, which is visible only to the assigned user when she joins a specific public channel, private channel, or private conversation! In the screenshot below, notice how "BitBot's" message is only visible to Janeth, who has just joined #pure-awesomeness channel on StdLib's workspace.

Get creative and add your personality to your bot or your company's brand! "

What You'll Need
1x Laptop
1x Slack Team
1x Creative and Daring Soul

About our speaker:
Janeth Ledezma is the Community Manager for StdLib and recent graduate from UC Berkeley — go Bears! When she isn’t learning Javascript or the Arabic language, you can find her riding Muir Wood’s loop or exploring Marin County on her motorcycle.

Twitter Handler: @StdLibHQ
Personal Twitter: @mss_ledezma

Website link: https://stdlib.com/
events.how_to_find_us: Look for a 'GDG Berkeley' sign up on the door. Call the number written on the sign and that will alert us to let you in.

events.name: Introduction to Extending Google Assistant
events.description:
Hello everyone!
GDG Berkeley & GDG East Bay (https://www.meetup.com/GDGEastBay) are excited to have Jessica Earley-Cha, a Developer Advocate for Google Assistant, as our speaker for the end of August!

Description: Learn about the latest dynamic in technology -- Voice User Interface (VUI). Learn how Google Assistant works and how you can leverage the platform with Dialogflow and Actions on Google to add an additional layer of access and interactivity to your users.

About the Speaker:
Jessica loves to connect with developers and explore VUI (voice user interface) to add another dimension to how user interact with technology. Jessica is a full stack developer who enjoys sharing knowledge and support others. Jessica is the co-organizer for Google Developers Group San Francisco, is a Women Techmakers lead and a teacher for Girl Develop It. You’ll find her either spending time with her dog, collecting strawberry knick knack or coding one of her many personal projects.
events.how_to_find_us: Look for a 'GDG Berkeley' sign up on the door. Call the number written on the sign and that will alert us to let you in.

events.name: Tensorflow.js: Machine Learning in Your Browser!
events.description:
TensorFlow is back with a twist! A twist of JavaScript.
We're happy to invite back Oswald Campesato to be our speaker for the month of October!

About the talk:

"This session starts with an introduction to Deep Learning concepts, followed by a quick tour of TensorFlow concepts, and then delves into tensorflow.js, along with some code samples. Basic knowledge of vectors, matrices, and derivatives is helpful for this session, which is intended for beginners and people who have not attended any of my previous Deep Learning presentations."

https://js.tensorflow.org/

About the speaker:

Oswald is a former PhD Candidate (ABD) in Mathematics, an education junkie (6 degrees), and an author of 19 technical books. He has worked for Oracle, AAA, and Just Systems of Japan, along with various startups. He has lived/worked in 5 countries on three continents, and in a previous career he worked in South America, Italy, and the French Riviera, and has traveled to over 70 countries on six continents. He has worked from C/C++/Java developer to CTO, comfortable in 4 languages, and dreams of becoming fluent in Japanese. Currently he is working in an AI start-up, and is an instructor at UCSC for a Deep Learning (100% TensorFlow) course, and conducts training in Deep Learning and Android.

Twitter: @ocampesato
events.how_to_find_us: Look for a 'GDG Berkeley' sign up on the door. Call the number written on the sign and that will alert us to let you in.

events.name: GDG Berkeley Holiday Party
events.description:
Please join us for our GDG Berkeley Holiday Party! This is a chance to connect with the other members of the GDG community and enjoy some holiday festivities. Please come with ideas and topics you'd like to see us address in 2019 and with ideas on how we can improve.

We would also love to have lightning talks from the community for the community, so any technical topic is welcomed if you'd like to present.

Food and drinks will be provided. We'll also have a raffle, so be ready for some *AWESOME SWAG* :)

Looking forward to seeing you all!

events.name: DevFest hosted by GDG Berkeley and GDG Modesto
events.description:
THIS EVENT IS SOLD OUT! (You must have registered on Eventbrite)

Let's get ready for our first DevFest hosted by GDG Berkeley and GDG Modesto on January 13th at Pacific School of Religion. The updated, new venue is Pacific School of Religion. Their address is 1798 Scenic Ave., Berkeley, CA 94709. When you arrive, please look for Chapel of the Great Commission, located at Le Conte Avenue. This will be the only building hosting DevFest activities throughout the day on Sunday.

Please join developers, students, and tech enthusiasts for the biggest Google tech conference in the East Bay. DevFest is a community-run, one-day conference aimed at bringing technology enthusiasts and experts together. About 100 people are estimated to attend DevFest, with speakers coming from all over. The talks will focus on Google technologies along with other emerging technologies such as Android, Flutter, Firebase, Google Cloud Platform, the Mobile Web, and the Google Assistant.

DevFest attendees will be able to familiarize themselves with new and emerging technologies, network, socialize, and help to build the growing tech community in the Bay Area. Anyone interested in technology is welcome. Each ticket includes talks from industry experts, gifts, and lunch.

Schedule available here => https://bayareadevfest.com/
events.how_to_find_us: From Downtown Berkeley BART Station (located at 2160 Shattuck Ave, Berkeley, CA 94704), Pacific School of Religion and Chapel of the Great Commission is about a 15 minute walk.

events.name: Google Cloud Study Jam
events.description:
Study Jams are community-run study groups for developers. This is a great opportunity for our community to come together and learn something new, together.

Attendees will receive free access to Google's online labs where we will start the GCP Essentials course as a group!

In this introductory-level quest, you will get hands-on practice with the Google Cloud Platform’s fundamental tools and services. You will come in with little, or no prior cloud knowledge and come out with practical experience that you can apply to any GCP project. From writing Cloud Shell commands and deploying your first virtual machine, to running applications on Kubernetes Engine with load balancing, GCP Essentials is a prime introduction to the platform’s features.

Venue space is limited to 20 people and will be first come first serve, please bring your laptop to participate!
